Comment: I am waiting for someone to identify the US constitutional provision which empowers the US Congress to annex another country/State. I find no power to annex enumerated in the US Constitution [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enumerated_powers]. International law recognizes annexation, in certain instances, via a treaty, but there is no annexation treaty. Non-treaty based annexation of another State is not an enumerated power nor does it seem to be a "necessary and proper" power. Congress doesn't possess the authority to annex.. "This government is acknowledged by all, to be one of enumerated powers. The principle, that it can exercise only the powers granted to it, would seem too apparent, to have required to be enforced by all those arguments, which its enlightened friends, while it was depending before the people, found it necessary to urge; that principle is now universally admitted. Comment: . . . oddly, this Kahala development will add five dwelling units to the island's inventory, yet seems very likely to widen the gap between housing and locals.  Hidden by stereotypes is the fact that the same zoning codes that underlie increased density in Kahala are applicable elsewhere.  This is the juicy part of the story and it relates to the rest of the island.
I assume the ordinance that makes this development legal is "cluster housing."  It allows for a more efficient way to provide the number of dwelling units on a large parcel that are already allowed within that zone.  it's a useful tool that can be used to provide more elegant solutions to denser living.
Within this Kahala example we see accelerants of dramatic gentrification, as well as existing routes toward smart growth.  The difference is intention--intention in public policy and individual action.

Comment: I'd be more inclined to go by time than mileage. Higher mileage means generally longer runs at a constant operating temperature which is fine for a belt. 

Over a window of time you have a greater number of start/cold/warm-up/hot/stop cycles which exerts more punishment on a rubber belt. More so in a province like ON with hot summers and cold winters.

If I had a car that was 3years/75k km vs a 6year/40k km - I'd change out the 6yr first. My 31 year old car has covered 86k km in those 31 years. I had the belt changed last year for peace of mind (third time it's been changed, 15k km since the last change).

Comment: I think Obamacare should be, and will be, seen as a transitional program -- transitioning from health insurance as a commodity, a widget, available only to those who can afford it to health insurance as a human right for everyone, consistent with church teaching.  Since 2010, government figures show that twenty million people who did not previously have health insurance, and who would not have it now without Obamacare, are insured.  That said, no one would argue, I don't think, that Obamacare is perfect or that it can't be improved.  Obamacare represents political compromise: the perfect can't be the enemy of the good.  Going forward, we need to continue the transition to genuine universal health care and the single-payer plan that will bring us closer to achieving it.

Comment: The article does little to educate the reader on what is proposed.  It should be noted that most of the users cited require data transport to large global regions, i.e. they must connect to the internet backbone that spans the world.  The backbone or long haul links are mostly privately owned in the US.  Likely the long-haul hub in Eugene is run by Centurylink.  While not explicitly stated, it sounds like Eugene/EWEB are going to lay a few miles of fiber just to allow privileged downtown customers to connect the the Centurylink internet backbone connection.  Federal rules require Centurylink to rent connections to operations like the Eugene/Eweb effort.  But here is the rub.  For $4 million, likely comcast or Centurylink would have laid more fiber than Eugene/Eweb will.  Both companies know how to run the physical layer of the internet.  The story writers should have asked how much Centurylink or Comcast would have charged to install the same network.  Could have gotten more for less.

Comment: It'd be nice if journalists did their own checking on "scientific" claims, if only by googling for -critiques- of any study cited. Of course, that would require knowing something about the subject in the first place instead of just accepting narratives.

Having a gun in the home is not a "risk factor" for DV in an objective sense, it only appears so because researchers from Kellerman to Hemenway -start- with a sample set of "homicides in homes" rather than "households with guns." It's equivalent to saying "cars are a risk factor" when all you look at are "households with fatal car accidents" as opposed to all car-owning households. 

Even the studies referenced in the claim show the largest risk factors are histories of domestic violence, excessive drug and/or alcohol use, and criminal affiliations.

This case may be a true exception, but it still has nothing significant statistically to do with "risks of household gun ownership" in general vis a vis family annihilation suicides.

Comment: "The gravamen of [failure to appear in the second degree] is the violation of a release or security agreement." State v. Eastman, 112 Or App 256, 258, 828 P2d 484 (1992). 
Neither ORS 162.195 nor any other statute in ORS chapter 162 defines "release agreement." However, release agreements fit into an overall statutory scheme, comprised of ORS 135.230 to 135.295, which provides for the pretrial release of defendants in one of three ways: (1) release upon personal recognizance; (2) conditional release; or (3) security release. ORS 135.245. A defendant must sign and submit a release agreement to the court regardless of which type of release is involved. ORS 135.255; Sexson v. Merten, 291 Or 441, 445-46, 631 P2d 1367 (1981). 

http://law.justia.com/cases/oregon/court-of-appeals/2002/a111347.html

Comment: I have been to Hazard, Kentucky. It is not ominous unless you consider Drain, Oregon ominous. The residents are rural Appalachian hill people who need jobs due in part to the Obama EPA's illegal war on coal. They are very much like Drain and many other single-industry rural communities in America, most of which don't have easy-to-make-fun-of names. Pruitt's announcement is a good thing for these people. The Register-Guard headline editor seems far more interested in mocking the town's name in the cause of potential future global warming than in helping the people who live there who have real problems right now. By the way, the town and Perry County in which it is located were named after a hero of the War of 1812, Oliver Hazard Perry, who was also famed for his battle flag motto "Don't Give Up the Ship" and the saying from his battle report "We have met the enemy and he is ours..." If the people of Hazard have anything like the courage of their namesake, I recommend not mocking them.

Comment: It's not really true that his poll numbers never waiver. According to a couple recent polls, Lib support is in minority government territory. An Angus Reid survey in early Oct. had the Libs and Cons effectively tied (35% to 35%) in support, as I believe did the most recent EKOS poll (34% to 33%), which had the biggest sample size of any recent poll or survery. Also, I believe a Forum poll conducted in mid-Sept. had the Cons ahead of the Libs (39% to 35%). Low information voters (i.e. those who pay little attention to the news and/or current events) are probably more likely to support a sitting government until an election is in sight. But Trudeau's government is serving up a lot of chances for the opposition to exploit. The big question as we approach 2019 will be whether the opposition led by untested Con and NDP leaders is up to the task.

Comment: I'm not smart enough to know if the Republican platform will lead to a presidential defeat or not. I'll leave that to others, like this author.

(I suspect they had to make the subtle switch in the term, since these "immigrants" would then be documented.)

What, exactly, is pejorative, about the term "illegal alien"? People in this country can only be here legally or illegally. Is there a third option? Similarly, they can only be citizens or aliens. Again, is there a third option?

So "illegal alien" precisely describes a person who is not a citizen and is residing here illegally. Period.

I understand why writers use the euphemisms: as editorial devices, they elicit more sympathetic responses. To these writers, the truth is pejorative. 

Stop it!

Comment: Rent stabilization has really bad long-term effects on affordability and the quality of the housing stock.

And at a 3% vacancy rate, there appears to be a steady population of people in Portland who are both in Portland and can afford those rates, so if one tenant gets to stay in a rent-stabilized unit, that prevents another prospective tenant from being able to move in - and where does that second tenant then go?  As I state above, it picks a current group of winners and makes everyone else, including all future potential renters, bigger losers by driving up long-term prices.

Amend the zoning laws for increased density, reduce parking minimums, create a housing subsidy fund for low-income residents, or have the city/county purchase and run low-income housing - all good ideas that can work.  But not rent control/stabilization.  It's simply not smart policy, however much it might be a feel-good, short-term fix for certain folks.

Comment: Here's the potential downside to Rob's advice, when someone lacking in knowledge chooses to go from an advisor to DB. Disclosure: I am an advisor and used to work at a major bank, so I'm speaking from second hand experience.

I'm not saying investing is super-hard and every investor needs people like me to do it, but here's what I saw a lot of when I was at the bank: people investing in regular commission-based, even back end loaded funds in DB accounts. Back in the day these were my prospects and my proposal to them was simply: "you're already paying the commissions... pay nothing extra and get a financial plan from me". 

That's where I see the investor in Rob's article going: moving it all to the bank's DB, keeping most of the same funds... bank's DB reaps all the trailing commissions without having to pay an advisor.

The investor's first move should be to start interviewing some other advisors, who aren't "fast-talkers".

Comment: Old news.

15 years ago, an electronics engineer that I know was hired by the CIA ( here in Canada) to secretly modify cell phones to be able to transmit even when turned off.  They told him that it was to spy on the mafia, but he recognized that the CIA doesn't deal with the mafia, so he assumed that the intent was simply to spy.  A few minor modifications and the cell phone could be turned on, and appear to be off, both to hear and photograph and then to transmit the data.

For a few years, every time he sat down, he would pull his battery out of the phone (separate battery in those days).  A couple of years later, he didn't remove his battery when he sat down and I asked why.  He told me that the CIA was now installing secret batteries to record even when the regular battery was removed.

He also told me that the cell phone companies were complicit in this spying, as they did not identify nor charge for the downloaded data usage.

That was 15 years ago.

Comment: I agree that the alternatives on offer are generally uninspiring, but that too was the case when Trudeau's Libs deposed Harper's tired regime. I would rather have Bernier leading the Cons and I see nothing compelling in any of the NDP's leadership aspirants. But governments tend to defeat themselves in this country. Trudeau's only accomplishments to date, like sort of getting along with Trump and a relatively robust but still fragile economy, have been achieved by default. But big minefields exist for the Libs on immigration, NAFTA and aboriginal affairs. On the latter issue, I suspect most Canadians have little interest in the models of aboriginal sovereignty proposed by many First Nations advocates. It will be almost impossible for Trudeau to achieve his vaunted new relationship with First Nations and keep the remaining 96% of Canadians mollified. And his broader predilection for identity pandering increasingly irritates many Canadians. The risks ahead are all Trudeau's to face.

Comment: The attack on Pearl Harbor was an attack on a military installation. The attack on Hiroshima was a direct attack on civilians and thus a violation -- and an outrageous violation, considering the massive and instant destruction of the bomb -- of the laws of war. To say that the Japanese began the war and committed many violations of the laws of war themselves is true and deeply problematic. But, as Catholics and as Americans, if our celebration of freedom means anything it means the capacity to choose the good even in the face of great pressure to do otherwise. And it means the capacity to face the truth when we fail to do so. Neither the attack on Pearl Harbor nor the war crimes of the Japanese (for which the Japanese government has apologized -- see Prime Minister Abe's statement marking the 70th anniversary of the end of the war) nor the intransigence at the end of the war by the Japanese leadership "made us" violate fundamental moral laws and drop the A-bomb. We should apologize.

Comment: The problem with the line of thinking that cuts the PFD is that it's premature.  The constitutional budget reserve was put in place for the very reason it is being used for.  To cover a deficit on a rainy year.  You can look back as little as 8 years ago to see the CBR value was only $2 billion.  Nobody was pining seriously for the dividend yet then.  And then oil prices went up, and so did our savings.  So to say the CBR cannot be replaced - that's what i call fear-mongering.  At today's prices it will not be replaced.  

The PFD is not paid out of the state budget or the CBR.  It is paid from the earnings on investments received by the prinicipal in the permanent fund.  It is completely sustainable without ANY oil contributions, albeit at a lower payout.  Which is why the government wants access to it.

It is, at this time, completely unnecessary to impact the people of the state except to make them more receptive to taxes and other income sources when this does become an issue.

Comment: 1/3
“Mandatory celibacy” is an oxymoron. Rightly understood, celibacy “for the sake of the kingdom” is a charism -- a gift, a calling -- in its own right. In scripture, it arises in the context of the expectation that the Second Coming of the Lord was imminent. There is no biblical warrant for linking it to ministry, still less for making it a requirement for ministry. Celibacy, like marriage, must be freely accepted as a vocation in its own right; it cannot (or ought not, anyway) be asserted as a condition for something else. Mandatory celibacy makes as much (and as little) sense as mandatory marriage. If a person is truly called to celibacy, that person will live a celibate life apart from whatever work he does -- he (or she) would live in celibacy apart from whether or not he (or she) was also called to priesthood.

Comment: It's a social contract, Art. As such there aren't codified penalties for violating it. But that's not to say there's no consequence for violating the Charter:

"Enforcement of guaranteed rights and freedoms

    24. (1) Anyone whose rights or freedoms, as guaranteed by this Charter, have been infringed or denied may apply to a court of competent jurisdiction to obtain such remedy as the court considers appropriate and just in the circumstances." - Charter of Rights and Freedoms

If your rights are violated, you may go to court to have the matter remedied. A famous such case was that of Maher Arar. He sued the Canadian government for violating his rights, and settled out of court for $10 million. That's a huge sum by Canadian standards and it was handed over by Stephen Harper, who's no champion of civil liberties.

If the government violates your Charter rights it can be heavily penalized, and should be.

Comment: China has issues with the rule of law, and human rights. But does anyone really care? The extradition treaty with China is unlikely to impact everyday Canadians. The only people that should be worried are Chinese citizens living in Canada.  So why do normal Canadians, those born here care?

I agree that some Chinese living in Canada might be innocent, but you have to assume that some accused of corruption or fraud are ACTUAL criminals. They defraud people in China, escape to Canada, and then defraud actual Canadians. The victims of extradition aren't even Canadian...

Obviously the chance of a Chinese criminal committing the same crime in Canada is small. But an extradition treaty does NOTHING that would hurt real Canadians. Yet, it prevents Canada from becoming a haven for Chinese criminals that might commit the same crimes against Canadians... if Canada gets more favorable trade terms with China out of this, its a Win-win IMO. Sucks for Chinese immigrants. But great for Canada.

Comment: This discussion thread seems to hinge on the concept of 'transubstantiation'

I think it a distortion to say that ...."it's ultimately from Jesus that we get the notion of transubstantiation"....

'transubstantiation' came in with Aquinas and his effort to explain things in Aristotle's Philosophical concepts. In that philosophy – as far as I can interpret it – everything is made up of a 'substance' (which seems to be a conceptual category) and 'accidents' which are the sensory appearances.

Frankly, the whole philosophy does not make much sense to me.

According to it, the 'Conceptual Category' (substance) changes during Eucharist, so that we say both bread and wine are now the presence of the Risen, glorified, sacrificed Jesus - whole and entire, body and blood soul and divinity – as the Church expresses it.

Though sensory realities remain the same – it looks and tastes like like bread, our Faith concept is that it is Jesus present. Thus 'trans-substance'! but not trans-accidents'.

Comment: I can appreciate the logic of your argument. My argument, which I didn't have enough characters in my last comment to fully develop, is basically that the role of the fully-informed human conscience should reign supreme in such matters. Now I'm aware of the fact that the bishops would say that a fully-informed conscience can never dissent from official church teaching. I'm in fundamental disagreement with them on that, and you can either agree with me or not that that's a valid position to hold. The fact remains that I hold it on a number of issues. So, to answer your question, the applicability of church teaching is not as important to me as the demands of my own conscience. I think the church always wants to make official teaching neat and clean on issues that are inherently messy. I believe that sometimes it's better to learn to live with paradox than avoid it. The church disagrees with me on that. My earlier comment sought to underscore the fact that the church is always evolving.

Comment: The rules are being abruptly changed.  It will affect physicians that were about to retire and may not be able to. Those that have already retired could be in trouble. 

Ontario docs have been without a fee increase for 5 years and fees have been reduced by 4.5% (at a minimum) compared to 2012.  Some fees have been cut in half, none have increased.  Other provinces have managed to increase fees over the same period. 

Physician incorporation with limited income splitting was negotiated in good faith and granted to physicians in exchange for fee increases about 15 years ago. The government set the rules and now they are reneging. This is the primary retirement savings vehicle for over 60% of physicians. 

Physicians are right to be upset. Most will stay in Canada, but not all. I will wait until the details are finalized.

Comment: I completely agree with your first paragraph and that it should be tested.

However, I'm not sure the Ontario test will be a valid one.  I think the basic income has to be universal and not means tested, to derive the benefits.  As it is Ontario will claw back 50% of earned income.

Upper income folks get a small disincentive to work when you raise the marginal tax rate from 50% to 54%.  Imagine the disincentive with someone on welfare, who have a negative effective tax rate.  Getting a job means a tax jump of more than 100%.

UI means every dollar earned makes you richer.

The question that must be studied is whether UI would generate more economic:

1)  growth through incentivizing achievers to start businesses, move to better jobs, or even just get a job since it means more money; or

2) drag through incentivizing slackers to work less since they can live the same.

I think the achievers have way more economic impact and so the former is true, but I don't know this.

Comment: A State lawyer who tells a Governor, or sometimes even a commissioner, something s/he doesn't want to hear puts his/her career on the line. I'm not an advocate of an elected and thus independent, sorta', AG, but I do believe the State needs a Solicitor General who serves for a prescribed term and is only removable for cause to represent the State or challenge the State in litigation without political interference.   I've framed lots of conversations with State lawyers with, "I didn't call you to ask you what to do, I called you to tell you what I was going to do and ask you how to make it legal. Comment: It's easy to increase natural resources per person by limiting immigration. It's not clear that the same is true for financial resources. Less people means a smaller economy, less cross-pollination of ideas and fewer opportunities for economies of scale. There's a reason why immigration isn't just supported by big business but by parties of all stripes, because we can only pay for stuff if we're earning enough compared to other countries.
Personally, I'd rather be able to afford an HTC phone made in Taiwan, a PS4 made in Japan, a ThinkPad made in China, and maybe someday a Tesla made in the USA. If that means giving up a piece of arable land in return, I'm quite okay with that.
Immigration keeps importing young, hardworking people whose taxes and demographics sustain our welfare system. We get them for free without having to pay for any of their daycare or decade-long education. All we need to do for this is to give them a spot in society. I think that's a good trade-off.

First, yes of course, Jesus is present in the Eucharist, and Jesus is God, and therefore the Eucharist is adorable.

Second, development of doctrine does not mean that every development is to be evaluated by the future as positive. As well as the Spirit guiding, the human element in development is very strong. Indeed the Evil One is very keen to get in on the act of development to lead us astray.

Given both of these, I would suggest that the Eucharist is preeminently sacred food as evidenced by the the manner in which it was introduced by Jesus. There are two reasons, IMHO, for today downplaying the Eucharist as an object of adoration: (1) it was introduced and served for a long time to displace frequent reception, and (2) emphatic adoration outside of mass is a uniquely Catholic practice. Eccumenism is a solid reason for down playing this practice.

Comment: I agree that humans may always desire some degree of FTF interaction, but I think "virtual" online edu may improve in quality to the point that it is "virtually" indistinguishable from traditional face-to-face interaction.  

Furthermore, if we REALLY want to reduce traffic--unlike rail, and at FAR less cost than rail--we could offer generous incentives to students to increase use of ever-improving online edu options, while doing the same to dramatically increase the number of workers-- many of whom can already do all or part of their jobs online--to "telecommute" from home and/or more decentralized satellite offices.
  
And if we hope to guarantee at least two years of higher edu for all--and do so "tuition free", or at least "debt free"--I think the only way this will be affordable may be to increase the number of students who use online options.  Thinking this will be affordable if everyone attends traditional "bricks and mortar" institutions of higher edu is wishful thinking IMO.

Comment: Newsflash to Michael Sean Winters: the centerpiece of Pres. Obama's tax reform efforts was a cut in the corporate tax rate from its current rate to around 28%. And Mitt Romney proposed a cut to 25%. This bill is far from perfect, & there are lots of provisions that are ridiculous, but I think it is a good beginning that hopefully sensible politicians will alter & tweak. The best idea is the tax on university endowments of a certain size, & some GOP members are floating ending the carried interest deduction.

Could Winters point to me the nearest "middle class" homeowners who have a mortgage in excess of $500,000 that will be devastated economically by capping (not eliminating) the mortgage deduction at $500K? 

So I would recommend that after reading the usual parade of horribles that Winters likes to throw against any idea he finds objectionable (look: the Kochs!), that the Vox piece analyzing the overall plan is a much more soberly critical read than this.

Comment: The biggest factor in our affordable rental housing shortage is the outsized US Military presence in the islands.

A huge share of housing in our residential neighborhoods goes to transient military families. As of May 2016, Hawaii had nearly 50 thousand active duty service members, tens of thousands with families living in off-base housing. Per capita, Hawaii has by far the highest number of active duty military in the country. 

Military families have also driven up the price of rental housing.  They are given between $2000 (single E1) and $4100 (senior officer with dependents) each month to spend on off-base housing. This is on top of their inflated Hawaii Cost of Living Allowance (CONUS COLA) of $215 - $707 per month, and other military pay and benefits. 

Locals just can’t compete with 50,000 tenants who get an extra $2200 to $4800 to spend on housing each month.

The Honolulu housing crisis could be fixed by sufficient on-base housing, and no housing allowances.

Comment: Once more we have an example of the price we pay for living where we do.  Jeremy Joseph Christian's murderous assault did not happen in the absence of disturbing red flags waved over the last 15 years.  The quandary we face as a society is that in our legal system, it is to a large extent true that each criminal act is adjudicated separately, and we have a difficult time preemptively locking people up because they crossed some nebulously defined line of "too many bad deeds."  That's the problem, maybe not precisely in this case as Christian was a convicted felon, but there are many examples of murderers who previously committed no crimes that rose to the level of serious jail time, but nevertheless had reputations of being "seriously bad dudes."

What to do?  Well, we could go the way of some other civilized countries like England where police are allowed to stop, detain, and hold citizens with little or no cause compared to what's now permissible in the USA.  Or then again, maybe not.

Comment: Avoid creating subsidies for electric vehicles--as an immediate policy, even better idea!  Incentives, like any government grants/programming, are hard to kill once they have been implemented.

What are these enormous subsidies for gasoline fueled vehicles? Certainly not $8,000 (in Quebec) or $14,000 (in Ontario) per vehicle.  Near as I can tell, most of the so-called subsidies for gasoline-fueled vehicles is actually about costing environmental damage, health costs, etc. on the basis that the consumer purchase price doesn't factor in these post-purchase "costs".   Using the same logic, then cigarettes, fast food, booze, TV and internet....well, everything, for that matter, is being subsidized because the purchase price doesn't consider post-purchase "costs".  

Subsidies for EV's are an inefficient and expensive way to achieve carbon reduction, and the subsidies tend to end up in the pockets of the already-affluent.   It's bad policy.

Comment: Catholic and Protestant school boards were created for Ontario in the BNA act. At the time Catholics were a persecuted minority in Ontario, as the Orange Lodge controlled much of the province's government. The Ontario Catholic school boards were a quid pro quo for Protestant school boards in Quebec. Well into the 1960's (Protestant) religious education was part of the public school curriculum in Ontario. Jews and other religious minorities were excused from these classes.

Comment: As a teacher of color who works at Harrison Park K-8, I have to respectfully disagree with Emily Toll. It is sad that teachers (mostly Caucasian) think they know what is best for minority students.  As a child, I had the experience of being in ESL classes for four years of my early education and had to miss electives such as music, PE, and art.  However, I would not trade what I learned in ESL for these enhancement classes.  These classes would not have helped me pass my exams in high school, the SAT, or getting a scholarship in college.  As I am able to converse in another language, I am able to talk to parents in their own language on a more personable level.  Most, if not all, parents expressed that they prefer to have their child(ren) in ESL. This is the general consensus among minority parents in any language.  To say that John Walden did not solicit input from ESL parents is disrespectful and slanderous. Students need to read, write, and do math--that is an equitable education.
